ui.settings_risk_max_dd_hint: Circuit breaker: Maximum total drawdown from high-water mark before system enters SAFE mode.
ui.settings_risk_consecutive_loss_hint: Number of consecutive losing trades before pausing trading to prevent tilt.

ui.settings_strat_rsi_period_hint: Lookback period for Relative Strength Index (Standard: 14).
ui.settings_strat_rsi_thresh_hint: Threshold for mean reversion. Buys if < (100-Thresh), Sells if > Thresh (e.g. 70).
ui.settings_strat_macd_min_hint: Minimum MACD histogram value required to validate a trend signal.

ui.settings_strat_min_rr_hint: Minimum expected profit relative to risk required to take a trade (e.g. 1.5).
ui.settings_strat_profit_mult_hint: Take profit level calculated as a multiple of Average True Range (Vol).

help_topics.title: P&L
help_topics.description: The difference between the current price of an asset and its purchase price. A positive P&L indicates a gain, a negative P&L indicates a loss.
help_topics.example: If you buy a stock at $100 and it's now worth $110, your P&L is +$10 (+10%)

help_topics.title: SMA
help_topics.description: The average of closing prices over the last N periods. Used to identify the overall market trend.
help_topics.example: SMA 20 = average of the last 20 candles. If price is above SMA, trend is bullish.

help_topics.title: EMA
help_topics.description: Weighted average that gives more importance to recent prices. More reactive than SMA to price changes.
help_topics.example: EMA 50 reacts faster than SMA 50 to market reversals.

help_topics.title: RSI
help_topics.description: Momentum indicator that measures the speed and magnitude of price movements. Ranges from 0 to 100. Above 70 = overbought, below 30 = oversold.
help_topics.example: RSI at 80: the asset may be overbought, a bearish reversal is possible.

help_topics.title: MACD
help_topics.description: Trend indicator that shows the relationship between two moving averages. Used to identify momentum changes.
help_topics.example: When the MACD line crosses above the signal line, it's a potential buy signal.

help_topics.title: ATR
help_topics.description: Measure of an asset's volatility. The higher the ATR, the more volatile the asset (riskier but potentially more profitable).
help_topics.example: ATR of $5 means the price fluctuates an average of $5 per day.

help_topics.title: Qty
help_topics.description: The number of shares or cryptocurrency units you own in a position.
help_topics.example: Qty: 10 AAPL = you own 10 Apple shares.

help_topics.title: Avg
help_topics.description: The average price at which you bought your shares. If you buy multiple times, it's the weighted average.
help_topics.example: Buy 5 shares at $100 and 5 shares at $110 = average price of $105.

help_topics.title: Standard
help_topics.description: Basic strategy using two simple moving averages (20 and 50 periods). Buy signal when the fast SMA (20) crosses above the slow SMA (50) - called 'Golden Cross'.
help_topics.example: Ideal for beginners. Follows established trends without too much complexity.

help_topics.title: Advanced
help_topics.description: Sophisticated strategy using three filters: EMA for trend, RSI for momentum, and signal confirmation. More selective than Standard, generates fewer but higher-quality signals.
help_topics.example: Combines EMA 50/150, RSI < 60 (avoids overbought), and waits for 2 confirmation candles.

help_topics.title: Dynamic
help_topics.description: Smart strategy that automatically adapts to market regime. Uses TrendRiding in directional markets and Advanced in choppy markets.
help_topics.example: Automatically detects if the market is strongly trending or consolidating and adjusts its strategy.

help_topics.title: TrendRiding
help_topics.description: Aggressive strategy that seeks to capture large trends. Uses wide stops (4x ATR) to avoid being stopped out prematurely during minor corrections.
help_topics.example: Perfect for strong bull markets. Aims for significant gains (>5%).

help_topics.title: MeanReversion
help_topics.description: Contrarian strategy that buys during temporary dips betting on a return to the mean. Uses Bollinger Bands to identify extremes.
help_topics.example: Buys when price touches the lower Bollinger Band, sells at the upper Band.

help_topics.title: Bullish Trend
help_topics.description: Indicates that the price is rising. The fast SMA is above the slow SMA. Generally a good time to buy or hold.
help_topics.example: Emoji üìà displayed = price is rising steadily.

help_topics.title: Bearish Trend
help_topics.description: Indicates that the price is falling. The fast SMA is below the slow SMA. Better to avoid buying or consider selling.
help_topics.example: Emoji üìâ displayed = price is falling steadily.

help_topics.title: Sideways Market
help_topics.description: Indicates that the price is oscillating without a clear trend. The SMAs are close to each other. Beware of false signals in this context.
help_topics.example: Emoji ‚û°Ô∏è displayed = market in consolidation, wait for a clear trend.

help_topics.title: Bollinger Bands
help_topics.description: Two bands around a moving average that widen when volatility increases and narrow when it decreases. Used to identify price extremes.
help_topics.example: Price touching the upper band = potentially overbought. Lower band = potentially oversold.

help_topics.title: Circuit Breaker
help_topics.description: Safety mechanism that automatically stops trading in case of significant losses or system anomalies. Protection against crashes and malfunctions.
help_topics.example: If you lose 10% in one day, the circuit breaker can stop the bot and liquidate positions.

help_topics.title: PDT
help_topics.description: US rule that limits day trades (buy and sell same day) to 3 per 5-day period if your account is below $25,000. The bot automatically respects this limit.
help_topics.example: With a $5000 account, you can only make 3 round trips in the same day over 5 days.

help_topics.title: Drawdown
help_topics.description: The largest loss suffered from the peak value of your portfolio. Key indicator of the risk taken by a strategy.
help_topics.example: Your account reaches $11,000, then drops to $9,500 = drawdown of 13.6%.

help_topics.title: Win Rate
help_topics.description: Percentage of winning trades compared to total trades executed. A good win rate is generally above 50%.
help_topics.example: 15 winning trades out of 20 trades = win rate of 75%.

help_topics.title: Stop Loss
help_topics.description: Automatic sell order triggered when the price drops below a certain threshold. Protects against excessive losses.
help_topics.example: Buy at $100 with stop loss at $95 = maximum loss of $5 per share.

help_topics.title: Take Profit
help_topics.description: Automatic sell order triggered when the price reaches a profit target. Allows to secure profits.
help_topics.example: Buy at $100 with take profit at $110 = profit automatically locked at +10%.

help_topics.title: Market Order
help_topics.description: Order executed immediately at the best available price. Guarantees execution but not the exact price.
help_topics.example: Used for emergency exits (stop loss) where speed is more important than price.

help_topics.title: Limit Order
help_topics.description: Order that only executes if the price reaches or exceeds a specified price. Guarantees the price but not execution.
help_topics.example: Buy limit order at $100 = only executes if the price drops to $100 or below.

help_topics.title: Stop Order
help_topics.description: Order that becomes a market order when a threshold price is reached. Used to limit losses.
help_topics.example: Stop at $95 on a position bought at $100 = automatic sale if price drops to $95.

help_topics.title: Trailing Stop
help_topics.description: Stop loss that automatically rises with the price but never falls. Protects gains while letting profits run.
help_topics.example: Trailing stop at $5: if price rises from $100 to $120, stop rises from $95 to $115.
